attributes.alt: Cover for Little Nita's Big Idea by Anna W. Bardaus. Cover shows a girl holding an open book with images coming out of the book. People hugging fruit and a city with balloons are bursting out of the open book.

elements.text: Read-Aloud Comprehension; Alphabet Knowledge; Phonological Awareness
Use Circle Time to talk about the alphabet
, engage children with song and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking,
How do the neighbors help Nita?
Produce at least 20 letter-sound correspondences; Write uppercase and lowercase letters.
Make plans and take steps to a goal.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions; Know that people can speak different languages.
Recognize good habits of nutrition and exercise.
Ask children to name words that begin like
Invite children to draw a Happy Hippo or a Queen’s Quilt.
What stories do we like to tell?
Choose a book about food. What fruits do you see?
How would you make a fruit salad?
Choose some play foods to make a healthy snack.
Write or draw to show how to make a fruit salad.
Paint a picture of a fruit salad. What colors will you use?
How can you use play clay to make different kinds of fruit?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the
Mind Builder to introduce the related vocabulary
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely and notice how Nita is making and carrying out her plan.
Make plans and take steps to a goal.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Show emerging proficiency on tasks requiring eye-hand coordination (draw pictures recognizable to child but not others; cut with scissors but may not be able to cut across page.
Help children identify a goal and make a plan.
Guide children to follow the steps needed to reach the goal of making a paper pizza.
What stories do we like to tell?
What plan does the character in your book make?
Pretend you have a big mess to clean up. Show me how you could make the table clean!
How can you work together to finish a puzzle?
Draw or write something you plan to do later.
Draw a picture of something you plan to do later.
Find the letters in Nita’s name. Are any of those letters in your own name?
Make a plan for building a tower. What is the first step? What do you do next?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build background, clap syllables, and introduce new vocabulary words
What is special about Nita’s fruit salad?
Contribute ideas and participate in group writing.
Make plans and take steps to a goal.
Recognize good habits of nutrition and exercise.
Ask children to identify pictures of different fruits.
Guide children to sort the fruits into fruits that name one
What stories do we like to tell?
How is the character in your book like Little Nita?
What healthy snacks do you like to eat? Why?
How do you know if a food is healthy for you to eat?
Draw or write to show a healthy lunch.
Draw the steps to show how to make a fruit salad.
What letters do you know in the word apple? What letters do you know in the word banana?
Make a table and then sit down to eat a healthy snack.

attributes.alt:
Big Chart of Big Ideas for The Voice in Rabbit's House. Animals are nervous after hearing a voice in Rabbit’s house.
Chart shows a rabbit, leopard, and rhinoceros trembling in fear when a caterpillar crawls into Rabbit's house. A frog helps caterpillar crawl out.

elements.text: Big Chart of Big Ideas: The Voice in  Rabbit’s House

attributes.alt: Cover for Little Nita's Big Idea by Anna W. Bardaus. Cover shows a girl holding an open book with images coming out of the book. People hugging fruit and a city with balloons are bursting out of the open book.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to talk about telling stories and introduce vocabulary word
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts,
Read closely to answer the weekly concept question:
What stories do we like to tell?
Write for different purposes; Independently write letters to make words or word parts.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions; Understands a growing number of relational words.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Ask children to take the storytelling pointer, point to a picture on the Big Chart and tell what is happening.
What stories do we like to tell?
Compare the characters in the book. Which did you like the most? Why?
Can you dress up like one of the animals from the story we read today?
Can you put the animals in  the story from smallest to largest?
Draw a picture of when you used a big loud voice. What label could you put on your picture?
Can you make a house for Caterpillar?
Can you build an animal that is big and an animal that is little?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to have children act out parts of the story and introduce the vocabulary words
If you were Nita’s neighbor, what would you do?
Share and repeat the details in  a text.
Write for different purposes; Independently write letters to make words or word parts.
Make plans and take steps to a goal.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
If you were Nita’s neighbor, how would you help?
What stories do we like to tell?
Imagine that you are a character in the story you are reading. Which character would  you be?
Pretend you are one of Nita’s neighbors. Let’s help make a delicious fruit salad!
Pretend the pattern blocks are pieces of fruit. Can you make a marvelous salad?
Imagine a delicious salad. Write about how it looks and tastes.
Choose colors for making a fruit salad. What colors did you choose?
What fruit in the story is your favorite? Can you write letters for some of the sounds that you hear?
